heading: sprechen sie internet deutsch?
subheading: as germans clamor for net access and tools like email, they leave their language behind them. german isn't what it used to be. by carter dougherty.
author: carter dougherty
text: german hasn't been the same since it met the internet. the internet, and in particular the web, prompted linguistic changes that recall those wrought by martin luther. the protestant reformer's 16-century translation of the bible from latin into german set the standard for modern german.see also: europe's internet challenge- - - - - -what luther did stuck with the german language for centuries. what the internet is now doing is still in its first decade. but its influence is already being widely felt."technology has brought tremendous changes into the language, consistent with what is happening in the society," said peter schlobinski, a linguist at the university of hannover who has conducted an extensive study of language use on the internet.the influence of the internet on german manifests itself in both appearance, because the language now looks different, and in substance, because germans have snapped up english words to describe the customs of the digital age.the cosmetic changes become apparent after a quick lesson in the language.the two predominant accents used in written german are the two dots over many vowels known as the "umlaut," and the "ess-tsett," a character which resembles the greek beta and sounds like an "s." another hallmark of the language is that all nouns are capitalized.the two factors make for a language that looks rather quirky to native english speakers. "the cat runs across the street and through the houses." in german: "die katze läuft über die straße und durch die häuser."writing a sentence like that becomes a crapshoot in the world of ascii characters."you never know whether the umlauts make it through on the other end," notes wilfried schütte of the institute for the german language, based in mannheim. anyone who uses german accent marks in email or on a newsgroup runs the risk of creating a "a symbol salad" which is at best ambiguous, at worst incomprehensible, says schütte. the workaround is to replace any vowel that has an umlaut with the same vowel -- without the umlaut -- followed by the letter "e." and an ess-tsett becomes "ss." these techniques, which before the internet were not widely used in germany but are perfectly understandable to any native speaker, change the aforementioned german sentence about the cat in the following manner: "die katze laeuft ueber die strasse und durch die haeuser."now throw in another fundamental principle of the internet: speed in communication. when time is money, the split second it takes to strike two keys simultaneously to create a capital letter is a waste."on the internet, language is also subordinate to the desire for speed," said schütte. thus, the model sentence takes one more step away from tradition: "die katze laeuft ueber die strasse und durch die haeuser."comprehensible, but is it german? there's the rub.the pared-down german is clearly preferred on the internet, in newsgroups, and chat rooms. the umlaut and the ess-tsett do not exist in internet addresses, and are unlikely to make a comeback, predicts the linguist schlobinski.these cosmetic changes do not bother traditionalists so much. they are limited to a digital world which traditionalists have been slow to inhabit. more infuriating has been the seemingly blistering pace at which germans have adopted english words to describe technology.the fledgling organization for the preservation of the german language is waging a war against such new verbs as "downloaden."in two years, this private organization has garnered 3,000 members, all of whom pay dues to support the cause. when the institute for the german language proposed that the words "upgrade" and "downloaden" be incorporated into german dictionaries, traditionalists revolted."i simply cannot understand this proposal," raged the organization's president, walter krämer. "for a large portion of the english computer jargon there are perfect and often better german words." efforts like these garner chuckles. in the 50 years since world war ii, the vast majority of germans wear their patriotism lightly if at all, and this attitude extends to language."pure ideology," jibes linguist schlobinski, who considers english words a practical solution to the problem of how to describe a global medium.english words are also a sign of cosmopolitanism in a country where politicians who speak no foreign languages are the butt of jokes in educated society. the professionals do not worry about the advent of "denglish," as the traditionalists like to call the german of the late 20th century.schlobinski also cautions against panicking about the imminent loss of the language, if only because the technology that has wrought these changes has shown a remarkable potential for changing itself. earlier in the computer age, all the world was learning dos command lines in english. but the graphical interface made words that were once necessary superfluous -- in any language.the tendency of germans to incorporate technology into their daily lives slowly, if at all, will also act as a brake on the internet's influence on language. in official written communication, nouns are still capitalized and umlauts are still required. and letters begin with the phrase "very honored so-and-so." inconceivable in an internet chat room, but still a very familiar phrase in germany.tradition will not go quietly. not yet, anyway.
